title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's men hoping to do their talking on the field amid racism worries
text:
Marcus Rashford and Harry Maguire have given their Manchester United team-mates a frank account of the “sickening” racist abuse England players suffered in Bulgaria last week as they steal themselves for the threat of more ugly scenes in Serbia on Thursday night.

Partizan Belgrade were ordered to play their two latest Europa League home matches behind closed doors due to “the racist behaviour of its supporters” in their third qualifying-round match against Yeni Malatyaspor of Turkey.

It has raised fears of more trouble and put Uefa and anti-racism campaigners on high alert. A capacity 30,000 crowd is expected at the Partizan Stadium for United’s first visit here since 1966.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said United would follow Uefa’s three-step protocol, which could culminate in referee Xavier Estrada Fernandez taking the teams off, should they encounter the “worst-case scenario”.

The United manager revealed he convened a meeting in the wake of the racist abuse suffered by England’s black players during their Euro 2020 qualifier in Sofia and that Rashford, one of those abused, and Maguire relived the experience.

“In the aftermath of what happened in Bulgaria, we had a meeting with the boys and we’ve gone through the protocol,” Solskjaer said. “But I believe in people and I’m sure the atmosphere here will be fantastic. We’ll try to keep them quiet by playing good football. We trust Uefa and, as Savo [Milosevic, the Partizan manager] said, hopefully it’s a celebration of football.
description: Marcus Rashford and Harry Maguire have given their Manchester United team-mates a frank account of the “sickening” racist abuse England players suffered in Bulgaria last week as they steal themselves for the threat of more ugly scenes in Serbia on Thursday night.
